comments.commentBody: My niece was required to take antibiotics for the first four months of her life to prevent urinary tract infections, as she was born with a blockage in her ureter and needs two surgeries to fix it. It was not a choice, and she still got infections since her blockage was so severe. I am not a proponent of using antibiotics liberally or irresponsibly, but in some cases, there is no choice and it is in the best interest of the baby.

Even more important is an end to the constant war making. We must reconsider spending sending our people to kill, and risk death and great injury to do it, and spending so much of our money to do it when we haven't enough for our other needs of food for all, medicine for all, and infrastructure decay.

Also more important is economic justice. The vast disparity of income and assets that has grown up over the last decades rivals the worst abuses of the 19th Century. It has broken our economy by limiting demand, it has broken our education system, and it is breaking down our basic democracy.

Those are more important than your priorities, although yours are also important.

Sometimes, truth is besides the point. In today's politics, its relevancy is certainly diminished. Its purpose is abandoned, standing as empty and eerie as the giant hollow factory shells in Detroit. Its role in the Presidential campaigns is over and under-rated, as one is about fear, the other about feel good.

The power of truth has always been tied to a sense of shame, a feeling of inner pain, a self-imposed humility, an emptiness and brokeness that rained on a soul telling a lie. Truth, celebrated as a virtue, carried with it a sense of embarrassment that made it hard to look people in the eye. Despair waited on those who bent or violated its moral faith. Truth is foremost an inner quality, a force that builds a fabric of trust.

Akin and the ensuing political arguments badly miss this point. His one sentence/word/day violated a larger, higher trust. During his political career, he campaigned on and legislated sexual politics, slashing women's rights and the integrity of their persons and bodies under cover of an intolerant faith. A day of reckoning and rebuke comes, as his did, swiftly and without warning. Still, he is blind, his tongue speaks with swift deceit and swaggers in its contempt. His utter lack of shame (funding raising even before he issued his defense!) should not be taken as strength. His responsibility should not be ignored even as others are tied--legitmately--to his views. Let him rush forward. But without redemption.

Mercy should never endorse the sin.

AT, you're still not getting it. Under any red light as yield rule, a pedestrian doesn't need to anticipate if a cyclist is responsible or not. If the pedestrian has the light, the cyclist must yield, period. The predictability of right-of-way on green is still maintained EXCEPT that bikes and pedestrians may now pass the intersection if nothing is crossing. The police can then focus their energies on ticketing both cyclists and pedestrians who cross on red when traffic is coming.

And while we're at it, we can and should get rid of a good many traffic signals citiwide. They're not needed. In fact, studies show an uncontrolled intersection is actually marginally safer than a signalized one. Without traffic signals, motor traffic would have to slow to 15 or 20 mph at each intersection or risk a collision. This would make things much safer for people crossing. Also, you can cross many Manhattan streets by using the subway mezzanine instead the crosswalk. I often do this because it's way safer than crossing a busy street at street level.
